greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers that are the sum of 2 distinct nonzero squares in exactly 1 way.
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
mathematica: nn = 229; t = Table[0, {nn}]; lim = Floor[Sqrt[nn - 1]]; Do[num = i^2 + j^2; If[num <= nn, t[[num]]++], {i, lim}, {j, i - 1}]; Flatten[Position[t, 1]] (* _T. D. Noe_, Apr 07 2011 *)

a[1] = 5; a[ n_] := a[n] = Module[ {s = a[n - 1], t = True, j}, While[ t, s++; Do[ If[ i^2 + (j = Floor[Sqrt[s - i^2]])^2 == s && i < j, t = False; Break], {i, Sqrt[s/2]}]]; s]; (* _Michael Somos_, Jan 20 2019 *)
program: s = filter(lambda x: x <= lim, (i*i for i in range(1, int(lim**.5)+2)))
s2 = filter(lambda x: x <= lim, (sum(c) for c in combinations(s, 2)))
return sorted(k for k in s2counts if k <= lim and s2counts[k] == 1)
results.author: _David W. Wilson_
